pros: Good potential of campaigns, able to meet a lot of people and spread the cause of gender equality
cons: In an organisation about gender equality and women's empowerment, the working space is perfectly contrary. The upper management tends to look down on associate positions and interns. Often demand work to be done quickly and gives no space to learn.

job_title: Graphic Design Consultant in Cairo, Cairo Governorate
pros: INGO working for a good cause of empowering women
cons: bad management, no career plan, tough atmosphere.

job_title: Reporting Officer in Dar es Salaam, Dar es Salaam
pros: Interesting work, contributing to women's empowerment. Working across the country with different organizations.
cons: Slow processes and some bureaucracy.

review_title: Needs to practice what it preaches
pros: As expected, the employees at UN Women come from all different types of backgrounds from around the world. The office is multi-cultural and everyone is mission-oriented, driven, and highly intelligent.
cons: Lots of paper pushing at this organization with little to no work-life balance. It's normal for people to work 12-hour days. Doing so is often portrayed as a point of pride but in actuality is a reflection of poor staffing and hiring practices that leaves young professionals doing mainly administrative work than research or analysis on the issues they care about. You need a master's degree to be considered for an internship, which is already a high barrier for entry especially since stipends and pay for consultants is no where near what's needed to survive in NYC.

pros: There are lots of room for improving oneself.
cons: Not easy to climb the ladder

pros: As an experienced in procurement & logistic ,who has a proven track record best value of money , Full compliance of procurement activities with UN/UNDP rules, regulations, policies and strategies; implementation of the effective internal control, proper design and functioning of a client-oriented procurement management system. I believe I would be an asset to your esteemed organization.
cons: The procurement service that I delivered was referred to as a success story at my position in both county and global level. With my exceptional communication skills and interest in career development, I am positive that I have much to add to your organization success in terms of Procurement & supply chain management.

pros: worthy mission, some dedicated colleagues
cons: Incompetent and abusive country rep. So many complaints from staff about her abuse of power, yet no consequences. Hierarchical and rigid.

pros: Much needed work to advance women’s rights, a number of excellent, dedicated colleagues
cons: Super dysfunctional management; employees, including numerous extremely competent ones, are taken advantage of.

pros: Passionate workforce with compelling mandate
cons: Hierarchical, bad management, lack of vision and direction from executive management, weak strategic alignment, complete lack of autonomy, no accountability, driven by internal politics and competing agendas of individuals in decision-making positions. Incessant competing demands not aligned to strategy and capacity. Lip service to principles of empowerment

review_title: A great mandate but need better management and more agility
job_title: Senior Consultant in New York, NY
pros: Delivering Impact at scale working on global projects and making a difference
cons: Lack of career development or growth and visibility very hierarchal, need to focus on building more inclusive culture globally. Need more focus on staff in small offices

pros: Excellent life-work balance and environment
cons: Hard to jump from contract to contract

pros: I like work with Un because it’s my dream
cons: I am very interested and I would like to work because I am a good leader

review_title: Motivated colleagues, inspiring mandate, but a not so healthy work environment.
pros: Many inspiring, interesting and motivated colleagues.
cons: There is a very strong sense of “passion” in the company which translates to a non existent work/life balance. Also, under consultancy contracts (under which most employees fall under) there are no benefits and the feminist labor principles that are preached from the organization outwards are not out in practice within the organization.

pros: Gender Champion within the UN system
cons: Limited resources and donor funding

pros: Great resource of knowledge on gender, many knowledge management products, great trainings, good for gaining expertise.
cons: Poor senior management over the team. Talent is lost and misused. High turnover. People are leaving fairly fast since they have not been offered any career prospect.

job_title: Project Assistant in Belgrade, Central Serbia
pros: Good salary and health insurance scheme
cons: Limited number of days for sick leave, not in line with locak practice Only 16 weeks for maternity leave, not in line with local practice

pros: Monthly salary, you can work from home and come to office two days a week
cons: It’s a slow machine that stalls all initiatives

pros: Committed and qualified people work here - mostly
cons: lack of feminist leadership at the top

job_title: Programmer Specialist in New York, NY
pros: If you have a staff contract, the benefits are great, like any other UN agency. Compared to other UN agencies, UN Women have more positions in capital cities rather then in the "deep field". Staff appear committed to the mandate.
cons: Having worked for several other UN agency in the past, UN Women appears as the most ineffective one, the least operational and is extremely burdened by an insane level of bureaucratic cumbersome rules. Every activity or request, even the simplest ones require non-ending memos and requests in Atlas, so many steps, for everything. I have never experienced anything like this with the other UN agencies. The agency is paralyzed by its own weight. The entire workforce appear to create jobs for themselves with unending paper pushing.  Another Con: UN Women being constantly under-funded while promising to over-deliver is reliant on a workforce of "non-staff", mostly an army of short-term consultants to provide "expert" advice. As a result, the turnover is extremely high and everyone is constantly looking for other jobs.

pros: professionalism is the best describe of the UNWOMEN.
cons: I did not find anything that need to improve because management were the best

pros:
Addresses underlying causes of gender inequalities

job_title: Staff Member in New York, NY
pros: Diverse, interesting projects, fast-paced, benefits are pretty good (including dental, vision and paid maternity/paternity leave) and you have access to many UN events. Everyone works very hard and there are almost no lazy people.
cons: They say it's a seven hour work day with an hour lunch break, but it is not the case depending on your workload and manager. International staff members get most of the best benefits (they get a rental subsidy and kids' tuition help if they were recruited from abroad) whereas national staff get nothing and have to deal with taxes whilst the internationals do not get taxed. There's a large divide between how staff, consultant and interns are treated. Sometimes mistakes are not forgivable. Pay is lower than other places, especially for New York City living, and the UN staff tax is high too.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros:
- Mandate is critical.
- There are some amazing staff and teams working in the organization, against all odds, and pockets of excellence which should be supported internally and by partners.
cons:
- The worst management every encountered in the UN system.
- Bullying, enormous egos, and chaos.
- Internally competitive and people falsely take credit for the work of others. 
- Shallow priorities amongst senior management with initiatives that provide flash and visibility of highest value.
- Culture totally misaligned with supposed values and mandate of the organization, i.e. empowering women, respect, human rights. 
- Many excellent staff  have left the organization w/o even securing another job first because the environment is so toxic. 
- Demotivating at any point in your career.

There are of course exceptions to the above depending on where and with whom you work. However, the overall culture and higher levels of management are terrible and this will eventually impact everyone in the organization and their ability to do their work well and to also find personal growth and reward. I would advise those interested in the mandate to consider working for UN Women when leadership changes and there is opportunity to right the ship.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in Cairo, Cairo Governorate
pros: profesional flexible understanding demanding learning
cons: demanding exhausting racism non non

review_title: Worst reputation within the UN system unfortunately well deserved!
pros: Potential to do things better and work more effectively in the hands of better management, especially country offices which tend to be small with some degree of flexibility. As things stand the cons far outweigh this potential however.
cons:
- Incompetent and overpaid management (middle and higher levels) - worst I have seen in any organization
- No accountability 
- Small budgets for country offices and even so there is still considerable waste due to bad management of project funds 
- Demoralizing work environment - rude staff, incompetent management, high staff turnover, no opportunities for career progression, low morale 
- Decisions taken based on whims/personal agendas rather than evidence or what is best for beneficiaries
- Lack of communication between management and staff 
- Compared to other UN agencies staff do not have a strong technical background (in programme development or thematic areas). Does not attract the best personnel, those who are good leave very quickly because of the poor management and terrible work environment
- Typical UN bureaucracy - lots of paperwork, slow to get things done, very hierarchical
- Technical staff expected to undertake significant amounts of clerical/administrative work
- Terrible reputation within the UN system which means that partners do not take you seriously and it is not looked upon well when you apply for other positions

pros: Great mission and mandate. Salary and other benefits are good for those on Fix Term contacts. Most colleagues are smart, very dedicated and nice to work with.
cons: Zero work-life balance, midnight emails from supervisor, work culture that expects to be on call 24/7, very little top-down communication and very little trust afforded to staff members at large. Management and senior staff at RO and CO (and Some cases HQ) look only after themselves, with mutual favors to advance their own career, oftentimes at expense of staff who are more junior to them. Very high turnover as dedicated people get excessively overworked with no credit or thank you, and either will end burned out or opt out themselves. Internal career mobility / advancement system favours those with no family (taking up a detailed assignment of several months in another duty station is not option for most women nor for some men who have children.)

review_title: Powerful mandate but poorly executed. Good salary and befits for full time staff
pros: Powerful and important mandate with good salary and benefits for a full-time staff. Supportive colleagues at a junior level. Great diversity of culture and mix of people from various interesting backgrounds. You can find some great motivated staff/teams at the junior to mid levels in the field offices.
cons: Lack strategic direction. Senior managements usually do not have technical expertise and/or understanding of gender equality and women's empowerment. This does not help to sharpen organization's strategic positioning and direction. Lots of emphasis on resource mobilization without appropriate levels of responsibility and/or accountability, especially for senior management to deliver their part. Lack emphasis on technical strengths at the field level.

review_title: Decent work, work environment could be better
pros: If it is your first time interning with the UN, then this is a good start. The work is decent, and gives you perspective, mostly because UN Women LEAP team works closely with other organisations such as Plan, Care, Action Aid, UNHCR and UNOCHA. If you are a full time intern you also get paid approx. CHF 1,000 in Geneva.
cons: The work environment is dull and boring, team work becomes tedious beyond a point, seniors do not have time to help out much. If there are no co-interns things might be difficult. Quality of work is not good enough to surpass these factors.

review_title: Good Experience with UN Women Procurement
job_title: Procurement Intern in New York, NY
pros: Very supportive managers. Very friendly working environment. UN Women is a very new organization, so there is a lot to learn and to contribute. Love my experience there a lot.
cons: Not much to say. But I would say that it's very important to choose the right team. My experience with my team is very positive but I also heard a lot of negative things about other bosses from other interns.

job_title: Programmer Analyst in New York, NY
pros:
Great mission and mandate: empowering women is crucial to development. Amazing junior level colleagues who are motivated and passionate toward making a difference. Great grass-roots level work.

Extremely cushy UN salary (junior/starting level makes about 70k net in NYC) plus very generous benefits  (housing allowance (up to 1k a month), 30 days paid leave, maternity, paternity, health, child education allowance (up too 30k per year per kid), 30k relocation, paid tickets to fly home with the whole family every other year, etc, but only for the small portion of the workforce in international (P and D) staff positions.

Little expected results and weak management oversight or enforcement: great for chronic slackers and over-the-hill bureaucrats who just want to cash in while traveling around on the corporate dime and waiting for retirement. Really perfect if you are politically or personally connected with management and want to pursue a side gig of finish up that part-time PhD while on the UN payroll.

Solid work/life balance if you're a slacker. You can literally not show up to the office for weeks at a time and face no consequences aside from, maybe, a toothless tongue-lashing (again, assuming you are staff, not consultants or interns).
cons:
Terrible work environment: constant uncertainty, unclear/low expectations, lack of vision, bad attitudes,  rampant sexism (toward men) and abuse (toward junior women) on the part of senior management.  Extremely demotivating for passionate and motivated young people.

Epic fear of direct "conflict" leading to unending backstabbing and politicking to undermine other teams'/people's initiatives leading to constant institutional deadlock. 

No link between performance and advancement or effort and outcome. No/awful institutional structures or systems  to support team/individual goals and projects makes everything being incredibly difficult and frustrating to accomplish.

Entitled mid-level to senior staff with sour attitudes who produce little and contribute less, and mostly end up sitting silently through (endless) meetings while staring at the ceiling or occasionally asking a banal or redundant question over the teleconference so people will know that they were in attendance.

Very patronizing and unfocused leadership; scatterbrained and nonstrategic approach to work leads to a massive waste of money and time and a very stressful and disappointing work environment; huge focus on "visibility"  (especially of personal visibility of in-county and senior management) leads to fragmented approaches and investment of institutional funds toward travel, pet projects, and personal aggrandizement.

Horrendous work/life balance if you are actually motivated and passionate because you have to carry a lot of dead-weight.

review_title: Make sure it's a fit for you
pros: Good place to work overall, especially if you believe in the mission. Good people work there at heart.
cons: Horrible environments, everyone is out for themselves. No risk taking. Human resources are treated terribly, especially consultants with zero benefits and zero tax support. Everything takes too long.

job_title: Programmer Specialist in New York, NY
pros: The mandate for women's empowerment and gender equality is terrific and staff are very dedicated to it. There are technical specialists here from all over the world with incredible backgrounds and experience.
cons: Management is very poor, bully junior staff and do not have clear roles or priorities. Some mid-level and senior staff treat their teams like servants or personal assistants, it can be demoralizing.

pros:
Passionate Team. Always treated as an important team player. Plethora of opportunities to get attend various UN events in Council Chambers, network with other agencies, and meet influential leaders. 

Additionally, UN Women in itself, is an ambitious agency. It has some great initiatives that have received international attention, especially the HeforShe campaign.
cons: The same issues that any large bureaucratic organization faces. They need to absolutely pay their interns! It is a young agency but, a part of a much older UN family. Need to coordinate better with other agencies in terms of administrative practices.

pros:
I've learnt a lot, my supervisors were really helping, there was also a great team spirit, people got along very well. 
Even though they couldn't hire me afterwards, it was a great internship and in hope it will help me work with other UN agencies.
cons:
Unfortunately it was only an internship, they didn't have money to create a special position as communication assistant so they keep working using interns. 
Also, the UN system never pays it's interns, so 6 months without any salary is a bit hard.

pros: Flexible working environment. Small team so opportunity to learn a lot and be given a lot of responsibility early on. Still a young organisation so culture is developing and is heavily influenced by each individual who is on the team at a certain point in time.
cons: Lack of leadership & strategic direction. Little support provided from HQ. Always seem to be responding to situations rather than planning ahead and being pro-active.

review_title: Great experience for those interested in international development
pros: As a recent grad, the office environment is excellent and everyone is dedicated to their jobs and were great mentors. Gained a lot of insights about the many stakeholders involved in international development. Additionally, the HR team had workshops to discuss professional development options.
cons: Internships are unpaid and transitioning into UN culture can be overwhelming. Specifically, understanding how organizations and agencies are connected, and the many acronyms.

review_title: Unpaid but lots of opportunities and responsibilities
pros: Lots of great networking opportunities, access to high level events, learned a lot, understanding management team
cons: Unpaid, very demanding schedule - most interns had so many responsibilities it left for little extra time to take advantage of events

review_title: Great people, poor leadership,  horrible bureaucracy
pros: There are some really dedicated staff that are knowledgeable and dedicated and are  working hard.
cons: Many of the upper level staff have no experience with women's right and are appointed for political reasons. They are more interested in securing their next prestigious well paying job than doing well in the  position they have now.

review_title: You'll lose your faith in the UN
job_title: Policy Specialist in New York, NY
pros:
Salary and benefits.
Fantastic colleagues (note: not "senior management" nor "mid-management").
cons:
Sexism! It's depressing.
You will likely get bored after one year.
Managers tend to be incompetent (there's, of course, some exceptions).
Opaque hiring practices.
Lack of knowledge of gender equality and women's rights. Management tend to be technocratic.

pros: You can find very supportive and like-minded colleagues here. Help arrives whenever you ask for it. Open for discussions and open to learn from each other. It's an opportunity with many great challenges to learn from.
cons: A bit still hierarchical (I worked at a country office), and higher level staff can be rather less open to disagreements.

review_title: It was a pleasure working in the UN Women budding environment.
pros:
There is a lot going on with lots of things for one to learn from.
The people I worked with are very friendly and encouraging.
The organization is trying to bring an effective end to a more-than-age-old problem of violence against women.
cons: Unfortunately, funding occasionally becomes an issue.

pros: To support society and the development and manufacture of women leaders that can have a clear impact on democratic processes
cons: Lack of targeted numbers in the humanitarian programs for women in the slums, compared to the regular areas

Treat staff very poorly, management does not seem to care about others, just themselves
Take too long to get things done, unecessarily bureaucratic

pros:
really good benefits
-health, vision and dental

cons:

-management style
-awful people and policies

pros: people committed to their work, do what they can

pros: Super nice supervisor; hold responsibility for your own long term project;  yoga; intern networking; workshops for employment development

pros: Great place to work, lovely people and you know you are making an impact

pros: I worked in a small dept so I was able to take on a lot of interesting projects. Networking is also a plus.
cons: Unpaid, a lot of other people in the UN system thinks UN Women is a mess.

pros: UN is a great environment and its values and mandate motivates you every day.
cons: UN is a great environment but overload is crazy. Anyhow is still a pleasure to work for UN.

pros: Very dynamic organization, open minded and ready for new initiatives, inspiring and engaging

pros: Good place to work with, lots to learn. Interesting area of work.

pros: Best place to work at. Management is extremely helpful

review_title: Low retantion rate, people come and leave
